awd_titl_txt: Professional Development Workshop for Raising Calculus to the Surface and The Vector Calculus Bridge Project
awd_abstract_narration:
Funded by the Improving Undergraduate STEM Education (IUSE) program, this faculty development workshop aims to increase faculty usage of new learning materials produced by two innovative projects that emphasize the geometric aspects of multi-variable and vector calculus. These projects, "Raising Calculus to the Surface" and "The Vector Calculus Bridge Project" also emphasize a learner-centered pedagogical approach. This three-day workshop will enable at least 24 university level mathematics faculty members to learn about the tools and pedagogy to support student learning of 3-dimensional calculus concepts. In the workshop, participants will also write materials for use in their classrooms. 

The geometric approach and small-group activities developed by the workshop organizers mesh well with the recommendations of the Mathematical Association of America's Curriculum Guide and its Instructional Practices Guide. In particular, since the workshop will be conducted by both mathematicians and physicists, the development of mathematical thinking and communication skills and the promotion of interdisciplinary cooperation will be featured. Features built into the "Raising Calculus to the Surface" materials encourage instructor adoption of these practices, and strong demand among instructors for the 3-dimensional surface manipulatives has previously been observed. An evaluation of the workshop will include surveying the participants and dissemination of the new materials.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The Professional Developmend Workshop for The Raising Calculus to the Surface Project and The Vector Calculus Bridge Project gathered 23 faculty from 22 institutions spanning high school, community colleges, private and public universities for an intensive four day wokrshop in June 2023. The Surface project utilizes physical manipulatives and small group activities to enable students to discover important concepts and relationships underlying multivariable calculus.  The Bridge project utilizes a geometric approach to vector calculus to help 'Bridge the Gap' between the way vector calculus is taught in mathematics courses and used in physics and science courses.  Both projects utilize geometric thinking, small group activities, and whole class discussion to engage students in the learning process. 

Although each project was developed independently, the two projects share significant viewpoints regarding the content and the use of studend ideas in the classroom. This workshop represents the first joint effort by the Surface and Bridge projects to conduct a coherent professional development workshop for instructors.

 Outcomes of the seminar included:

1) Provide instructional support for at least 24 university level mathematics faculty members to adopt the materials for their classroom

2) Provide instructors with practical experience teaching with materials designed for a learner-centered pedagogical approach and gain practice facilitating small group and whole class discussion.

3) Disseminate the materials to the instructors for use in their own classrooms

 

The worskhop was designed to provide instructors with significant support and help in adopting and adapting the project activities for their own classroom.  Instructors experienced activities from a student perspective - including the accessibility of geometric understanding and engaging in whole class discussion centered around student ideas - before discussing the pedagogical advantages and opportunities afforded to both the instructor and student from this introduction to the material.  Subsequent discussions helped unveil the pedagogical moves workshop leaders employed to facilitate whole class discussion, including how activity leaders promoted ideas, organized discussion, and used these ideas to drive content forward.  Workshop participants also gained experience implementing activities and facilitating classroom discussion when they co-led one of the project activities.

Sessions during the workshop focused on helping instructors think about how to adapt and adopt activities into their own multivariable and vector calculus courses. These sessions focused on pedagogy and content. Workshop participants were provided a classroom set of Surface and Bridge materials. Instructors indicated they were excited to implement the activities in their own classroom in the subsequent year and to share the materials with colleagues in their own mathematics department or other science departments.
